data.title: Schwarzenegger Backs Off His Stance Against Gay Marriage
data.meta_description: Gov Arnold Schwarzenegger, softening statements against gay marriage, says on Tonight Show that it would be 'fine with me' if Californians change law to permit same-sex marriages; opposes federal constitutional ban on grounds that such issues belong with states; photo with host Jay Leno (M)
data.text:
Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger surprised many advocates of gay marriage last week when he warned on national television that the issuance of marriage licenses to same-sex couples could result in bloodshed.

Mr. Schwarzenegger was on television again on Monday night but this time he threw opponents of gay marriage for a surprise, including many from his own Republican Party.

The governor said it would be ''fine with me'' if Californians changed the state's family code to allow for same-sex marriages. He also said he opposed a constitutional amendment backed by President Bush that would ban them.

''I think since we have a state law, I think those issues should be left to the state,'' Mr. Schwarzenegger said on NBC's ''Tonight Show.'' ''So I have no use for a constitutional amendment or changing that at all.''

The apparent softening of Mr. Schwarzenegger's public stance had proponents of same-sex marriages rejoicing on Tuesday and opponents feeling betrayed. But advocates on both sides predicted he had not spoken his final words on a subject that has provoked a national debate.

''I think that after the election, we will try and have a serious talk with him and see if we can come out with a more reasonable position,'' said State Senator William J. Knight, a conservative Republican who was the author of a successful ballot measure in 2000 opposed to same-sex marriages. ''It is hard to tell what Arnold does until we talk to him, and pin him down and say, 'These are the issues, and we think you are going to have to come out with a position.' ''
